content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: Supine position, lower limb at rest with the anterior aspect of the hip exposed[1]

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Locate and palpate the greater trochanter

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Observation of the femoral neck (and surrounding structures)
parametres: Exceptionally, a curvilinear probe will be used, considering the considerable depth of the imaged structures
positionnement: As shown in the attached image, in oblique longitudinal view (almost parallel to the long axis of the femur), place the probe on the femoral neck, slightly distal to the greater trochanter [GT] (or at the same level in some subjects)
Scan slightly proximally and distally until obtaining an optimal image, i.e., one in which both the femoral head and neck are visible

texte: The femoral head appears in the center of the image as a semi-circular area bounded by a hyperechoic line

The femoral neck appears to the right (distal) of the femoral head. It is a hyperechoic area with a concave relief (which is not very pronounced given that the image was obtained using a curvilinear probe)
The acetabulum is present just to the left (proximal) of the femoral head, and appears as a hyperechoic area with a poorly defined contour (the outline of this image suffers from some distortion)

The iliopsoas is superficial to the femur (thus at the top of it in the image), and takes the form of a slightly hyperechoic area within which muscular echotexture (rather wide striations) is visible. The fascias surrounding the iliopsoas, more echogenic than the internal portion of the muscle, are also clearly visible
The portion of the joint capsule visible in this image is located between the femoral neck and the lower border of the iliopsoas

text: The femoral neck is the portion of the proximal femur that connects the femoral head to the femoral shaft. It forms an angle of approximately 125° with the femoral shaft in adults[1]. This angle, called the neck-shaft angle or caput-collum-diaphyseal (CCD) angle, varies with age and can be an important clinical indicator.

The femoral neck is almost entirely intracapsular, meaning it is contained within the hip joint capsule. This anatomical arrangement has important clinical implications, particularly in cases of fracture, as it can affect blood supply and healing potential.

The surface of the femoral neck serves as an attachment site for the hip joint capsule and several ligaments. The capsular attachment extends further on the anterior surface than on the posterior surface, leaving a portion of the posterior neck extracapsular.

The blood supply to the femoral head passes primarily through vessels that run along the surface of the femoral neck, making this region particularly vulnerable to vascular compromise in cases of fracture or dislocation.

content.subtitle: Femoral Neck Fractures
text: While ultrasound is not the primary imaging modality for diagnosing femoral neck fractures, it can be useful in identifying joint effusion and assessing surrounding soft tissue injury.

The femoral neck is a common site of osteoporotic fractures, particularly in elderly patients. The orientation and architecture of the femoral neck make it particularly susceptible to fracture under certain loading conditions.
Understanding the normal ultrasonographic appearance of the femoral neck and surrounding structures can help in the assessment of post-fracture healing and complications.

content.subtitle: Developmental Conditions
text: Ultrasonographic examination of the femoral neck region can be helpful in screening for developmental hip dysplasia in infants.

Changes in the neck-shaft angle (coxa vara or coxa valga) can be assessed to some extent through careful ultrasonographic examination, though other imaging modalities are typically used for definitive diagnosis.

content.subtitle: Osteoarthritis
text: Ultrasound can be used to assess some aspects of hip osteoarthritis, particularly the presence of joint effusion and synovial thickening.
The relationship between femoral neck morphology and the development of hip osteoarthritis has been well-documented, making understanding of this region's anatomy particularly important.
